archdesc.runner: Special Collections, Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Earl Gregg Swem Library, College of William and Mary
did.abstract: Personal and business correspondence of Jay Winston Johns, Jr. (1888-1974), coal industrialist from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and later an "adopted son" of Virginia, becoming a leader in preserving homes of renowned Virginians.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to all researchers.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights/Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Before publishing quotations or excerpts from any materials, permission must be obtained from the Curator of Manuscripts and Rare Books, and the holder of the copyright, if not Swem Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Jay Johns Papers, Manuscripts and Rare Books Department, Swem Library, College of William and Mary.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: Jay Winston Johns, Jr. was a coal industrialist from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, who moved to Virginia and became a leader in preserving homes of renowned Virginians. He married Helen Lambert (1881-1964). Johns became blind in the late 1950's.

He and his wife owned "Ash Lawn," Albemarle County, Virginia which had been the home of James Monroe and designed by Thomas Jefferson. Johns was founder of the Lee-Jackson Memorial, Inc., a foundation dedicated to preserving the memory of Robert E. Lee, Thomas Jonathan "Stonewall" Jackson and the South's part in the Civil War; and a founder of the Virginia Trust for Historic Preservation, an organization whose main purpose was that of purchasing, restoring, and maintaining for the public, homes of renowned men specifically, the Lee-Fendall House in Alexandria, Virginia.

Johns, himself was a strong Democrat and corresponded with and publicly supported all of the prominent Virginia political figures of his time. He was a spirited supporter of the Virginia Military Institute as a member of the Board of Visitors, and as an honorary member of the Alumni Association; a charter member, and later trustee of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts; and a member of the Virginia Chapter of the Society of the Cincinnati. He also received an honorary degree from the College of William and Mary in 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The collection contains mostly personal and business correspondence of Jay Winston Johns, Jr., including papers of the Atlas Fuel Corporation of New York, New York and Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania; Lee-Jackson Memorial, Inc.; the Virginia Trust for Historic Preservation; and "Ash Lawn," now owned by the College of William and Mary.

The correspondence of Johns includes correspondence with Virginia Democratic Party figures such as Albertis S. Harrison, William M. Tuck, Mills Godwin, Harry F. Byrd, Sr. and Carter Glass. Other prominent correspondents are Morton G. Thalhimer, Harry de Butts, James J. Kilpatrick, and George C. Marsall. There are records of social occasions given by Mr. and Mrs. Johns, correspondence relating to her illness and death, and papers relating to his death.

The collection includes a manuscript collection by Johns including original items by Phillip Brooks (1835-1983), George Washington Parke Custis(1781-1857), Albert Gallatin (1761-1849) and D. H. Hill (1821- 1889); as well as typescripts and photocopies of Includes letters written by Thomas Jonathan Jackson, Francis Lightfoot Lee, Mary Custis Lee, Richard Henry Lee, and Robert E. Lee; and materials concerning James Monroe and Ezekial Moses.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection has been organized into ten series. Series 1 contains personal papers; Series 2 contains papers from the Atlas Fuel Corporation; Series 3 contains papers from Lee-Jackson, Inc.; Series 4 contains papers from the Virginia Trust for Historical Preservation; Series 5 contains miscellaneous materials; Series 6 contains miscellaneous interests; Series 7 contains papers pertaining to Ash Lawn; Series 8 contains the manuscript collection; Series 9 contains manuscript volumes and other miscellany; and Series 10 contains oversized material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has been arranged into series with multiple subseries. The subseries, for the most part, have been arranged alphabetically by persons last name or by subject and then further ordered chronologically by date. Additional descriptions concerning the arrangement of specific subseries can be determined at the subseries level.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: This collection of James Monroe Papers was donated by Jay Johns and includes Includes letters by, to and concerning James Monroe, as well as a few printed items.

p.archref: Jay Johns Collection of James Monroe Papers, Manuscripts and Rare Books Department, Swem Library, College of William and Mary. Jay Johns Collection of James Monroe Papers, 1780-1834. 84 items. Mss. 68 M75

did.unittitle: Material concerning "Stonewall" Jackson and the Jackson family, 1852-1895, n.d.
T[homas] J[onathan] ["Stonewall"] Jackson, Lexington, Virginia, to "brother" [Warren Jackson], n.p., 1 September 1859.

scopecontent.p: Discusses Anna's [Morrison Jackson]sickness and search for medical treatment from Dr. Watkins of Prince Edward County, Virginia.

did.unittitle: T[homas] J[onathan] ["Stonewall"] Jackson, Mount Jackson, Virginia, to Colonel Bassett French, Aide-de Camp to Governor of Virginia, n.p., 21 March 1862.

scopecontent.p: Requests that Colonel French ask the Governor [of Virginia]to order 3,000 muskets; discusses those opposed to war and how he plans to give them departmental jobs. Including Pst Tcy of ads, 21 March 1862, from T[homas] J[onathan] ["Stonewall"] Jackson, Mount Jackson, Virginia, to Colonel and Basset French, n.p., discussing the use of bayonets when firearms cannot be supplied. 1 page. Including endorsement signed by S. Bassett French, stating that he referred information to General [Robert E.] Lee.

did.unittitle: T[homas] J[onathan] ["Stonewall"] Jackson, Gordonsville, [Virginia], to "Doctor," Rev. W[illia]m S. White, D. D., Lexington, Virginia, 20 June 1862.

scopecontent.p: Discusses securing an army appointment for Mr. Goul [?]; requests that everyone pray to God for a blessing of "their" [the South's] cause.

did.unittitle: T[homas] J[onathan] ["Stonewall"] Jackson, Bristow, [Virginia], to General J. R. Trimble, n.p., 29 August 1862.

scopecontent.p: Praising him for success and promoting him by offering him two new Regiments.

did.unittitle: T[homas] J[onathan] ["Stonewall"] Jackson, Lt. Gen[era]l, [near Chancellorsville, Virginia,] to Gen[era]l R[obert] E. Lee, n.p., 2 May 1863.

scopecontent.p: States plans to attack enemy at Chancellorsville, [Virginia] as soon as possible.

did.unittitle: Includes letters concerning the Jackson family, 1852-1895, n.d.

Margaret Junkin [sister-in-law of "Stonewall" Jackson], Lexington, Virginia, to Sartain, n.p.,
12 February [18]52.

scopecontent.p:
Requests that he publish more of her literary works in the
Sartainmagazine.

did.unittitle: Start W[illiam] Arnold, Department of the Interior Washington, D.C., to "Mother" [Laura Ann Arnold], n.p., 31 August 1866.

scopecontent.p: Encloses twenty-five dollars for her.

did.unittitle: Stark [William Arnold], Washington, D.C., to "Mother" [Laura Ann Arnold], Beverly, West Virginia, 28 August 1868.

scopecontent.p: Wants to meet her in Grafton, [Virginia], and go to Springfield, [Virginia], together.

did.unittitle: [Anna "Grace" (Arnold) Evans], Washington, D.C., to "Mother," Laura A[nn] Arnold, Beverly, West Virginia, 17 July 1870.

scopecontent.p: Discusses weather and encloses Col. Clarke's bill.

did.unittitle: M[ary] Anna Jackson, Lexington, Virginia, to John Dimitry, n.p., 8 September 1877.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for tribute to the memory of her husband.

did.unittitle: Stark W[illiam] Arnold, Friendship, Allegany County, New York, to "Mother" [Laura Ann Arnold], n.p., 23 August 1895.

scopecontent.p: Discusses financial situation and interest on Roaring Creek, [Pennsylvania].

did.unittitle: Margaret Junkin [sister-in-law of "Stonewall" Jackson], Lexington, Virginia, to Sartain [?], n.p. 14 January [?].

scopecontent.p:
Wants to include some of her literary work in his magazine
Sartain.

did.unittitle: Material concerning Robert E. Lee and the Lee family, 1778-1894, n.d.
Printed material and prints about Robert E. Lee.
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Virginia], to "Rob" [Robert E. Lee, Jr.], n.p., 22 July 1863.

scopecontent.p: States that his daughter, Agnes, is sick and must go to the doctor; family news.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, Richmond, [Virginia], to Miss Markie C. Williams, n.p.,
20 June [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Discusses his wife's illness; family news; says that he has done "nothing wrong [referring to his indictment for treason] and cannot flee."

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Virginia], to Mr. L. R. Spilman, Att[orne]y at Law, n.p.,
10 July [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Discusses the estate of the late George Washington Parke Custis.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Virginia], to Hon. Reverdy Johnson, Baltimore, Maryland, 27 July 1865.

scopecontent.p: Expresses thanks for the offering of his professional services concerning the indictment; talks about General Grant's letter that was sent to him.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Virginia], to Mr. W[illia]m D. Cabell, n.p., 27 July [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Discusses imprisonment of Mr. McCue's son.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, [near Cartersville, Virginia], to Mr. John B. Cocke, n.p.,
28 July [18]65.
did.physdesc: 1 page.TCy of ads. Including XCy of ads. 3 pages.

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for taking care of his horse; daughter Agnes is still confined.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, [near Cartersville, Virginia], to Miss Norvell Caskie, "Derwent," [Virginia], 29 July 1865.

scopecontent.p: Reports that Anna Logan arrived in buggy by Capt. Owens; met Capt. Bridges at Belmead.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Virginia], to Mrs. Caroline Benson, n.p.,
29 July [18]65.

scopecontent.p: States that he is enclosing lock of hair and photograph [of himself].

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Virginia], to his son Fitzhugh [Lee], 29 July 1865.

scopecontent.p: Discusses issue of his war indictments.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, of Virginia], to Col. Walter H. Taylor, n.p., 31 July 1865.

scopecontent.p: Requests information to recognize "bravery and devotion of the Army of Northern Virginia."

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, Virginia], to Col. Rich[ar]d S. Maury, n.p.,
31 July [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Talks about suffering of the people of the South and his concern for their welfare.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, Virginia], to General [Wade Hampton], n.p., 1 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Gives details of his last battle at Appomattox Court H[ouse], [Virginia].

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, Virginia], to "Brother Carter" [Carter C. Lee], n.p.,
18 August [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Family news; discusses possible profits from publication of his works.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, Virginia], to W[illia]m D. Cabell, Richmond, [Virginia],
21 August [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Regrets that he is too old to take charge of Mr. Cabell's farm.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville. [Cumberland County, Virginia], to "Bertus" [Robert E. Lee, Jr.], n.p., 21 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear of his son's sickness; much family news.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, Powhatan County, Virginia, to "Gentlemen" [Messrs. John W. Brockenbourgh[sic], Rector, S. McD. Reid, Alfred Leyburn, Horatio Thompson, D. D., Bolivar Christian, T. J. Kirkpatrick, Committee], Washington College, [Lexington, Virginia], 24 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Regrets that he feels he cannot accept the position of president of Washington College.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County], Virginia, to
Rev[eren]d Philip Slaughter, n.p., 26 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Endorses General Long's statements "in favour of your young kinsman."

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County], Virginia, to Hon. John Letcher, Lexington, Virginia, 28 August 1865.

scopecontent.p: Express strong feelings about union of the people in an effort to restore peace; has been offered presidency at Washington College.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, Virginia], to
REv[eren]d Philip Slaughter, n.p.,
31 August [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Endorses General Long's statements "in favour of your young kinsman."

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County], Virginia, to A. M. Kelley, Petersburg, Virginia, 4 September 1865.

scopecontent.p: Declines job proposition with regret.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County], Virginia, to Count Joannes, City of New York, [New York], 4 September 1865.

scopecontent.p: Expresses gratitude for the offering of legal services if he is tried for treason.

did.unittitle: R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County], Virginia, to Captain Josiah Tatnall, Savannah, Georgia, 7 September 1865.

scopecontent.p: States positive attitude about everyone aiding the country in its restoration.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, Virginia, to "Captain" [Capt. Matthew Fontaine Maury, Mexico],
8 September [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Rejects Maury's idea of starting a new country in Mexico in order to fight for the United States' restoration; asks that Maury stay in Virginia and help in the restoration.

did.unittitle: Mrs. Robert E. Lee [Mary (Custis) Lee], n.p., to "Miss Em" [Miss Emily Mason], "Derwent," [Virginia], 10 September 1865.

scopecontent.p: Refers to Mrs. [Jefferson] Davisliving in Augusta, Georgia; says that Mrs. Davis knows nothing of her husband and that the curfew is strict for everyone, white and black.

did.unittitle:
R[obert] E. Lee, near Cartersville, [Cumberland County, Virginia], to Col. Rich[ar]d. S. Maury, n.p.,
11 September [18]65.

scopecontent.p: Refers to Colonel Maury's father's plans in Mexico.

did.unittitle: Printed Material about the Lee Family.
Material concerning the Lee Family, 1778-1894, n.d.
Richard Henry Lee, Philadelphia, [Pennsylvania], to Patrick Henry, esquire, Governor of Virginia, Williamsburg, [Virginia], 21 October 1778.

scopecontent.p: Discusses financial situation concerning payment of Continental troops and others.

did.unittitle: Francis Lightfoot Lee, Richmond, [Virginia], to "dearest" [?], n.p., 5 July 1780.
Cha[rle]s Carter, Shirley, [Charles City County, Virginia], to Henry Lee, esquire, n.p., 20 May 1793.

scopecontent.p: Gives consent for Henry Lee to marry his daughter.

did.unittitle: C[arter] C. Lee, Richmond, [Virginia], to "cousin Nat," Nat[haniel] Burwell, Staunton, Virginia, 1 February 1848.

scopecontent.p: Much family news; discusses farming and corn crops; wedding of cousin Ann Wickham's son.

did.unittitle:
C[arter] C. Lee, Richmond, [Virginia], to "Nat," Nat[haniel] Burwell, Roanoke County, Virginia,
25 June [18]48.

scopecontent.p: Much family and friend news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] C[ustis] Lee, Baltimore, [Maryland], to Abbey Louise Peters [Cook], [Saratoga, New York], 22 August [1850].
did.physdesc: 2 pages.XCy of ads. Including TCy of ads. 1 page.

scopecontent.p: Her son Custis is in his first year at West Point; give news of various engagements and weddings; inquires about matrimonial prospects; family news.

did.unittitle:
Alfred Lee, Wilmington, Delaware, to N[athaniel] Burwell, n.p.,
10 February [18]52.

scopecontent.p: Discussing pricing of Dr. Butler's book The Life of the Apostle Peter.

did.unittitle: William Henry Fitzhugh Lee, Baltimore, [Maryland], to "Brother" [George Washington Custis Lee], n.p., 15 February 1852.
did.physdesc: 2 pages.XCy of ads. Including TCy of ads. 2 pages.

scopecontent.p: Inquires about his grades; Uncle Smith is to go to sea and take command of the Princeton; talks of going to college; describes a grand ball that took place; family news.

did.unittitle: G[eorge] Washington C[ustis] Lee, Jackson, Mississippi, to Lt. Genl. Pemberton[?], n.p., 26 December 1862.

scopecontent.p: Referring another note to Lt. Genl. Pemberton for his appropriate action.

did.unittitle: M[ary] Custis Lee, New York, New York [?], to Abby [Louise Peters] Cook, Richmond, Virginia [?], [ca. 27 January 1865].
did.physdesc: 1 page.XCy of ads. Including TCy of ads. 1 page.

scopecontent.p: Talks about the "millenary line" of work; a great number of weddings and parties going on.

did.unittitle: Mary (Custis) Lee, "Derwent," Virginia, to Miss Emily Mason, n.p., September 1865.

scopecontent.p: General Lee accepts Lexington position to teach; grieves over situation the southern people are living through.

did.unittitle: Mary Custis Lee, Lexington, [Virginia], to [?], 16 September 1873.

scopecontent.p: Expresses gratitude for others' consideration and memory of her husband, General Robert E. Lee.

did.unittitle:
H[enry] Lee, n.p., to Mrs. Fendall, n.p.,
6 May [18]86.

scopecontent.p: Expresses appreciation for her "maternal tendency" talks of being under a doctor's care.

did.unittitle: H[enry] Lee, [Philadelphia, Pennsylvania], to R. S. Garnett, Congress, Washington, D.C., 21 January, 1894.

scopecontent.p: Discusses writing an article for the papers concerning landowners and tariffs.

did.unittitle:
[?, Baltimore, Maryland], to
George W[ashington] Custis Lee, West Point, New York, [ca. 15 February?].
did.physdesc: 2 pages.TCy of AL. Including XCy of AL. 2 pages.

scopecontent.p: Talks about "fast" Baltimore girls; many people sick with meazles [sic]; family news.

did.unittitle: Charlotte W. Lee, cousin, Arlington, [Virginia], to Nat[haniel] Burwell, Staunton, Virginia, 30 April [?].

scopecontent.p: Thanks him for the gift of apples; mentions Lucy Carter's, a cousin, wedding; family news.

did.unittitle: M[ary] C[ustis] Lee, n.p., to C. D. Walker, n.p., n.d.

scopecontent.p:
Enclosing money for her son
[George Washington] Custis Leeand herself.

did.unittitle:
Alfred Lee, n.p., to
N[athaniel] Burwell, Jr., n.p., n.d.

scopecontent.p: Thanks for the check and encloses a receipt.

did.unittitle: Correspondence and information about Ezekial Moses.

c01.head: Series 4: Virginia Trust for Historical Preservation

did.unittitle: Virginia Trust for Historical Preservation, 1967-1974, n.d.
Papers concerning the Lee-Fendall House, 1970-1974, n.d.
Correspondence concerning the Lee-Fendall House, 1970-1974, n.d.
Business Papers: Financial and Legal Items.
Printed material about, miscellaneous histories, maps, etc.
Newspaper Clippings concerning Jay W. Johns.
Photographs identified with Mr. and/or Mrs. Johns.
Preservation Interests including material on Fort Necessity, Pennsylvania; Prestwould Farm; and dealers catalogues.

scopecontent.p: Including a ticket to the 1936 Democratic National Convention; a history of the city of Alexandria, 1774-1783; an autobiographical sketch of Anthony-Charles Cazenove; 1971 Roster of the Cincinnati; Virginia Municipal Review; and Annual Report, 1958, of Charlottesville Woolen Mills.

did.unittitle: United Daughters of the Confederacy, Breckinridge Chapter. 1928-1954, n.d.
Miscellaneous materials, including a brief history of the chapter, program schedules, newspaper clippings, and pamphlets.

scopecontent.p: These materials include the American Foundation for the Blind, an address delivered to the graduating class at Staunton Military Academy by Jay Johns [?], receipts, poems, a print, and lists of names.
For additional material relating to this series see Series 10: Oversized Material located at the end of the collection.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning the Buildings and Grounds.
Correspondence concerning the Buildings and Grounds.

scopecontent.p: Items, including photographs and printed material, deal primarily with the Statue of James Monroe.

did.unittitle: Correspondence concerning the History of Ash Lawn.
Correspondence concerning L. G. Hoss and the rental of Monroe items.
James Monroe Material. James Monroe Material.
Correspondence concerning the birthplace of James Monroe.
Correspondence concerning the bust of James Monroe.
Correspondence concerning celebrations in honor of James Monroe.
Correspondence concerning the family bible of James Monroe.

scopecontent.p: For additional material relating to this series see Series 10: Oversized Material located at the end of the collection.
This subseries is arranged alphabetically by persons last name.
Phillips Brooks, Boston, [Massachusetts], to " Gen[era]l Secretary," n.p. Agrees to deliver an address at the opening service of the Church Congress.

did.unittitle: George Washington Parke Custis, Arlington House, [Virginia], to Benson J. Lossing, Poughkeepsie, New York, 19 June 1854.

scopecontent.p: Is recovering slowly, but still depressed; has begun painting as much as possible; tells of his "Surrender of York Town" as still hanging in the Rotunda of the Capitol, and being well received; the horses were particularly noted; describes his newest project, including "Trenton," and his use of original profiles by Sharpless [?] in drawing "the Chief" [George Washington]; comments on an article published in the Home Journal concerning mysterious truths connected with General Washington; is pleased at being considered for designing the tomb of [General Washington ?]; gives facts about the President's March, "Hail Columbia."

did.unittitle: Description of Arlington Spring by [George Washington Parke Custis], n.d.
Albert Gallatin, Springhill, to Ephraim Douglas, Uniontown, 18 November 1789.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of possible legal action to be taken against Daniel Weibel, a carpenter living on Gallatin's plantation, who owes a sum of £30-40 to him.

did.unittitle: Check for $160.00 made payable to William and John Wister, 18 December 1800.

scopecontent.p: Signed by Albert Gallatin.

did.unittitle: Receipt for $100.00 from Albin Mellier for furniture from Gallatin's home on Friendship Hill, Fayette C[ourt] H[ouse], Pennsylvania, 2 July 1832.

scopecontent.p: Signed by Albert Gallatin.

did.unittitle: Albert Gallatin, New York, [New York], to A[lbin] Mellier, Rockland near Baltimore, Maryland, 1 July 1832.
did.physdesc: 1 page.ads. In French. Including XCy and translation. 2 pages.

did.unittitle: Albert Gallatin, Astoria, to [John Russell] Bartlett, Astor house, [New York, New York], 10 September 1846.

scopecontent.p: Health has improved, but change in weather is adversely affecting him; returns Dr.[] Dickinson's specimens; wishes he could personally become acquainted with him [Dr. Dickinson].

These items include a souvenir booklet about Friendship Hill, Fayette County, Pennsylvania; map showing Gallatin property; and correspondence between Jay Johns and others concerning the possible purchase of Friendship Hill.

D. H. Hill, Office of "The Land We Love," Charlotte, North Carolina, to Henry R. Howeland, n.p. Reports that [?] Johnston is in Europe, but that W[illia]m Johnstonin Baltimore, [Maryland], should be able to supply the requested information.

W[illia]m Lee, Treasury Department, Washington, [D.C.], to Col. [?] Symmes, Collector, Alexandria [Washington], D.C. Report of three cases of furniture (parts of curtains, footstools, fire screens) belonging in the President's house, having arrived from Havre on board the ship Atlas.

did.unittitle: Xeroxed copies of autographed/signed Includes letters, 1778-1889, n.d.

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by correspondents last name.

did.physdesc: 2 pages.XCy of ads. Including XCy of a portrait. 1 page.

scopecontent.p: L[ouisa] C[atherine] A[dams], Washington, [D.C.], to [?]. Expresses "mortification" at the refusal of a friend, Eliza [Monroe?]to visit her because of the unfinished state of her home.
C. W. Andrews, Shep[?], to [?]. Information given about the construction of a symbol representing the 13 states, to be built with wood.

G. T. Beauregard, New Orleans, [Louisiana], to
W[illia]m B[ur?]well, Sec[retar]y and Treas[uerer] [of the] Chamber of Commerce, New Orleans, [Louisiana]. In regards to a circular sent from the Savannah, [Georgia], Chamber of Commerce relative to a proposed canal through the southern states, connecting the Mississippi River to the Atlantic Ocean.
Tho[ma]s N. Burwell, Fincastle, [Botetourt County, Virginia], to [?]. Mainly business letter discussing the transportation and accounting of a crop of hemp; his sister had a baby girl, and is fine.
Mayo Cabell, Union Hill, to Nathaniel Burwell, n.p. Business letter informing him that the amount of $150.00 due for his horse has been credited to his account at the Farmer's Bank.

J[ubal] A. Early, Lynchburg, [Virginia], to Gen[era]l A. R. Lawton, Savannah, Georgia. Questions figures given by [Joseph E.] Johnstonin his recent book about the Civil War concerning the Battle of Richmond in 1862.
Receipt signed by William Fitzhugh for money received from the Treasurer [of the Continental Congress?] as allowance for the October Session [in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania].

did.unittitle: J[ames] L. Kemper, Richmond, [Virginia], to Colonel John S. Mosby, n.p., 2 July 1874.

scopecontent.p: Sends all of their correspondence for the past year that he could find.

did.unittitle: James L. Kemper, near Orange C[ourt] H[ouse], Orange County, Virginia, to General Henry M. Cist, n.p., 24 May 1889.

scopecontent.p: Would like to have a copy of the reprint of General Boynton's Includes letters concerning the Battles of Chattanooga and Chickamanga; tells of the death of General Robert Emmet Rodes of the Army of Northern Virginia, 19 September 1864.
W. Meade, Millwood, to Nathaniel Burwell, Baltimore, Maryland Gives instructions for him to follow upon his [Burwell] arrival in Washington, [D.C.] involving Bishop Lee and Dr. Butler; family news.

Jo[h]n Pope, Head-Quarters, Department of the Northwest, Milwaukee, Wisconsin, to Maj. Gen[era]l P. H. Sheridan, U.S.A., n.p. Congratulations upon Sheridan's recent victory [at Opequon?]. Including ads., 4 August 1965, from Edward T. Downer, Cleveland, Ohio, to Jay [Johns], n.p., commenting on the Pope item.

A. Smead,
A[ssistant] I[nspector] G[eneral], H[ea]d Q[ua]r[ter]s, V.D. to Maj. Gen[era]l Ewell, [?] Division. Relays message from
Gen[era]l [Thomas Jonathan] Jacksonto have cavalry remain where it is.
I. R. Trimble, Manassas, [Virginia], to Gen[era]l[?], n.p. Reports the capture of Manassas, and his loss of men.

S[amuel] W[illia]m Tunstall[?], n.p. to Nathaniel Burwell, Western Asylum, Staunton, Virginia. Tells of dinner at a neighbor's home, and of Mr. and Mr. Gilmer also being guests; suggests that he not return home yet.
G[eorge] Washington, Mount Vernon, [Virginia], to Ja[me]s Marshall, n.p. Is in need of a horse, and asks him to be on the look-out for one that will fit his requirements.

L. M. Woodward, Western Lunatic Asylum, [Staunton, Virginia], to Na[thaniel Burwell], n.p. Mention of the "Harpers Ferry tragedy"; W[illia]m Bayloris on a "bridal tour" at Niagara Falls; Dr. Echelberger and Sue Baylor were married in the Lutheran Church; also, Mr. Funkhouser and Miss Scott were married, and both couples are also visiting Niagara Falls; comments that "even old Bachellors Would like to get married"; gives news of death of servant Sally.
Contains manuscript volumes, scrapbooks, journals and awards.

did.unittitle: Daily Journal of Jay W. Johns, 1919.
Distinguished Service Award of Jay Johns, given by the Civil War Round Table, 1 May 1971.
Resolution that Jay W. Johns be elected as an Honorary Member of the Board of Directors of VEPCO, 17 December 1971.

Certificate of membership in the President's Council conferred on Jay W. Johns "in recognition of his able counsel, advocacy, and financial support of the College of William and Mary in Virginia," 1973.
Stock Certificate book of the Atlas Fuel Company.
Scrapbook containing items relating to the James Monroe Bust Unveiling Ceremony and Ash Lawn.
Scrapbook containing items relating to James Monroe.
Engraving plate of the Stonewall Jackson Memorial depicting an equestrian statue of Thomas Jonathan "Stonewall" Jackson.
Scrapbook containing items relating to James Monroe.
Scrapbook containing items relating to Ash Lawn.

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by correspondent.

did.unittitle:
Diplomas and Certificates of Jay Winston Johns,
1934-1956.
Annual convention of the National Rivers and Harbors Congress, 1935.
Annual Convention of the Atlantic Deeper Waterways Association (Delegate representative, Virginia), 1935.

Diplomas and Certificates of Helen Elizabeth Lambert,
1899.

scopecontent.p: Saint Joseph Academy.

did.unittitle:
Diplomas and Certificates of John Lambert Molyneaux,
1922-1926.

Diplomas and Certificates of Therese Denise Molyneaux,
1916-1929.
Diplome de Francais University De Dijon, 1926.

scopecontent.p: Pst of U.S. Military Academy diploma of Thomas Jonathan Jackson; Pst of Sketch and site of the Battle of Port Republic, Virginia; Blueprint of Jackson Homestead; Jackson's Mill, West Virginia; Miscellaneous Virginians.

Photographs include the following:
Slave quarters at Ash Lawn
Views of the house
Tricia Nixon and Jay Johns at Ash Lawn
Print for a magazine article on Ash Lawn

did.unittitle: Blueline drawings of Ash Lawn by student of K. Edward Lay, School of Architecture, University of Virginia, Fall semester, 1979.

Set of plans for replica of Oak Hill at Ash Lawn by Edward Campbell,
1933.

scopecontent.p: Land patent signed by Henry Lee, Governor of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Reproduction from a photograph from the life of "Stonewall" [Thomas Jonathan] Jacksonwith a manuscript fragment attached bearing his signature, 1864.

scopecontent.p: Printed at bottom: "Entered according to act of Congress A.D. 1864 by C. B. Richardson in the clerks office of the district court of the United States for the southern district of New York."
